docs.abstract: “We’re the laughingstock of the world,” President Trump said during a 40-minute news conference with Giuseppe Conte, the visiting Italian prime minister.
docs.snippet: “We’re the laughingstock of the world,” President Trump said during a 40-minute news conference with Giuseppe Conte, the visiting Italian prime minister.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump reiterated on Monday his threat to shut down the federal government this fall if Congress does not deliver on Republican demands to crack down on immigration by enforcing security on the border with Mexico and building his long-promised wall.

headline.main: Build Border Wall or Government Will Be Shut Down, Trump Says
headline.print_headline: Trump Again Threatens a Government Shutdown Over His Border Wall

byline.original: By Katie Rogers and Nicholas Fandos

docs.abstract: The new Futures Command, breaking the traditional model of an Army department, will aim to get new weapons rapidly from the lab to the battlefield.
docs.snippet: The new Futures Command, breaking the traditional model of an Army department, will aim to get new weapons rapidly from the lab to the battlefield.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The platoon of Army Special Operations soldiers was on a routine night patrol in eastern Afghanistan when one of them suddenly opened fire on what looked to the others to be a bush.

headline.main: Army, Struggling to Get Technology in Soldiers’ Hands, Tries the Unconventional
headline.print_headline: To Get Technology in Soldiers’ Hands, Army Adopts ‘Futures Command’

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

docs.abstract: Officials have justified the war in Afghanistan as necessary to stopping extremists who targeted American interests. But the Islamic State, Al Qaeda and the Taliban all have a foothold.
docs.snippet: Officials have justified the war in Afghanistan as necessary to stopping extremists who targeted American interests. But the Islamic State, Al Qaeda and the Taliban all have a foothold.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For 17 years, three successive presidents have told the American public that above all else, Afghanistan must never again provide “safe haven” to terrorist groups seeking to harm the United States and its interests.

headline.main: U.S. Braces for Return of Terrorist Safe Havens to Afghanistan
headline.print_headline: U.S. Officials Brace for Return of Terrorist Safe Havens to Afghanistan

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

docs.abstract: The Pentagon says the military is too stretched to both fight insurgents and prepare for war with great world powers.
docs.snippet: The Pentagon says the military is too stretched to both fight insurgents and prepare for war with great world powers.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States is switching its priority to countering Chinese and Russian military might after almost two decades of focusing on the fight against terrorism, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said Friday, unveiling a national defense strategy that Pentagon officials say will provide a blueprint for years to come.

headline.main: Military Shifts Focus to Threats by Russia and China, Not Terrorism
headline.print_headline: U.S. Shifts Focus to China And Russia, Not Terrorism

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

docs.abstract: The president is looking at options that would go beyond last year’s missile barrage, which did not curb Syria’s war effort in the long run.
docs.snippet: The president is looking at options that would go beyond last year’s missile barrage, which did not curb Syria’s war effort in the long run.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump and his advisers on Tuesday weighed a more robust retaliatory strike against Syria than last year’s missile attack, reasoning that only an escalation of force would look credible and possibly serve as a deterrent against further use of chemical weapons on Syrian civilians.

headline.main: Trump Weighs More Robust Military Strike Against Syria
headline.print_headline: U.S. Considers More Intensity For Syria Strike

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

byline.original: By Peter Baker, Helene Cooper and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

docs.abstract: The Pentagon is poised to scale back patrols and commanders’ authorities as a result of the October ambush in Niger that killed four American soldiers.
docs.snippet: The Pentagon is poised to scale back patrols and commanders’ authorities as a result of the October ambush in Niger that killed four American soldiers.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A draft military investigation into the deadly ambush of American soldiers in Niger in October calls for the Pentagon to scale back the number of ground missions in West Africa, and to strip commanders in the field of some authority to send troops on potentially high-risk patrols.

headline.main: Inquiry of Soldiers’ Deaths Urges Curtailing West Africa Missions
headline.print_headline: Inquiry of Soldiers’ Deaths Urges Curtailing West Africa Missions

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

byline.original: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt

docs.abstract: The commander for forces in Africa said a request was submitted some time ago to add Niger, where four American soldiers died last year, to the danger zones where troops earn more pay.
docs.snippet: The commander for forces in Africa said a request was submitted some time ago to add Niger, where four American soldiers died last year, to the danger zones where troops earn more pay.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House has yet to approve a Pentagon request to provide imminent-danger pay to American troops assigned to Niger, a top military commander said on Tuesday, raising new questions about the support given to service members who are sent to West Africa to help in the fight against terrorist groups.

headline.main: White House Yet to Approve Danger Pay for Troops in Niger, General Says
headline.print_headline: Still No Approval of Danger Pay for Troops in Niger, General Says

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

byline.original: By Helene Cooper and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

docs.abstract: The guilty plea of one of Skadden’s lawyers has cast a spotlight on its work for a Russia-aligned former president of Ukraine, and its advice to other firms.
docs.snippet: The guilty plea of one of Skadden’s lawyers has cast a spotlight on its work for a Russia-aligned former president of Ukraine, and its advice to other firms.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For much of its 70-year history, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom has been a go-to firm for Wall Street, representing corporations like Pfizer and DuPont in acquisitions and becoming the first law firm in history to broker $1 trillion in mergers in a year.

headline.main: How Skadden, the Giant Law Firm, Got Entangled in the Mueller Investigation
headline.print_headline: Mueller Investigation Exposes Quiet Sideline Pursued by Law Firm

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP

keywords.value: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

byline.original: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Matthew Goldstein

docs.abstract: Intelligence and law enforcement officials had said the information was highly delicate and that it was not appropriate to turn over unredacted material to Congress.
docs.snippet: Intelligence and law enforcement officials had said the information was highly delicate and that it was not appropriate to turn over unredacted material to Congress.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House brokered an agreement on Monday with intelligence and law enforcement officials that will allow Republican congressional leaders to view some of the most highly classified information related to the Russia investigation, administration officials said.

headline.main: Republican Leaders Will Be Allowed to See Some Information on Russia Investigation
headline.print_headline: G.O.P. Leaders to See Some Details on Inquiry Into Russian Meddling

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

byline.original: By Michael D. Shear and Nicholas Fandos

docs.abstract: The president warned in a tweet that he may have to “use the powers granted to the Presidency and get involved” in the conflict between the lawmakers and the deputy attorney general.
docs.snippet: The president warned in a tweet that he may have to “use the powers granted to the Presidency and get involved” in the conflict between the lawmakers and the deputy attorney general.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump plunged into an angry dispute on Wednesday between conservative House Republicans and the deputy attorney general, siding with hard-line lawmakers over his own Justice Department as they pressed for access to sensitive documents related to the special counsel’s investigation and other politically charged cases.

headline.main: Trump Joins House Attacks Over Investigations
headline.print_headline: President Joins House Attacks Over Inquiries
